Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Algebra and Discrete Mathematics at Auburn University
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ten undergraduates will assemble for 8 weeks at Auburn University in each of the summers 2016-2018 to conduct research in algebra and discrete mathematics. This program is a continuation of successful REU programs conducted by the proposers at Auburn in prior years. The pattern of activities will be as before: intensive introduction to problems and problem areas in the first 2-3 weeks, capped by an obligatory "ice-breaker" presentation by each participant in the 3rd week, followed by a "research institute" phase in the remaining 5 weeks, capped by a final presentation by each participant. During the research institute phase there will be frequent talks given by faculty and graduate students of the department, visiting mathematicians, and the participants themselves, but the main feature of that phase will be research carried on by the participants, in various combinations with faculty, graduate students, and themselves. The purpose of the program is to give the participants an authentic experience of mathematical research.

This REU focuses on some of the current research problems in algebra (computational algebra, Groebner bases) and discrete mathematics (graph theory, graphs and hypergraphs, number theory, information and coding theory). As in past years, results will be published in books or refereed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016-2019 Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) in Algebra and Discrete Mathematics at Auburn University successfully produced many good results:

Ten publications resulting from work done during the REU programs have appeared in peer-reviewed journals, one other paper has been accepted for publication, two others have been submitted, and one is still being written. Participants have given conference presentations at the Joint Mathematics Meeting and the Southeastern International Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory, and Computing. Students have made significant discoveries and obtained many new results in the areas of graph theory, combinatorics, number theory, and algebra.

Students participating in the REU have gone on to enter graduate programs in mathematics and have participated in the Masamu Advanced Studies Institute (MASI) and Workshops in Mathematical Sciences. The Institute and Workshops, which are part of the NSF US-Africa Collaborative Research Network in Mathematical Sciences (NSF Award #1343651), are held annually in Southern Africa in conjunction with the Southern Africa Mathematical Sciences Association (SAMSA) Annual Conference.

The REU program has had a large number of female participants, and through a partnership with the Greater Alabama Black Belt Region Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (GABBR LSAMP, NSF Award #1712692), an increased number of underrepresented minority students have been able to participate in the REU program.

Application numbers for the program increased each year, demonstrating program enjoyment and satisfaction among participants and word-of-mouth advertising to their peers. In addition to the NSF-funded participants, several international and domestic students have participated by securing their own funding through their universities or external sources.
